clusters.title: Woman, 53, becomes UK’s longest survivor of heart and lung transplant
clusters.neutral_headline: Woman, 53, becomes UK’s longest survivor of heart and lung transplant

items.title: Woman, 53, becomes UK’s longest survivor of heart and lung transplant
items.standfirst: Katie Mitchell had procedure at 15 after being diagnosed with Eisenmenger syndrome, a rare congenital diseaseAt the age of 15, medics feared Katie Mitchell was coming to the end of her life after suffering irreversible lung damage and heart failure from a rare congenital disease.But she defied the odds thanks to a heart and lung transplant, and at the age of 53 she has become the UK’s longest-surviving recipient of such a procedure. Continue reading...
items.content: Katie Mitchell had procedure at 15 after being diagnosed with Eisenmenger syndrome, a rare congenital diseaseAt the age of 15, medics feared Katie Mitchell was coming to the end of her life after suffering irreversible lung damage and heart failure from a rare congenital disease.But she defied the odds thanks to a heart and lung transplant, and at the age of 53 she has become the UK’s longest-surviving recipient of such a procedure. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Katie Mitchell, 53, is the UK's longest survivor of a heart and lung transplant.
She received the transplant at age 15 due to Eisenmenger syndrome.
Eisenmenger syndrome caused irreversible lung damage and heart failure.
The transplant saved her life, defying medical expectations.
She has lived for 38 years after the transplant.

clusters.title: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns
clusters.neutral_headline: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns

items.title: High youth death rates are an ‘emerging crisis’, global health study warns
items.standfirst: Alcohol, suicide and injuries driving rises among teenagers and young adults despite overall rates falling, authors say The world faces “an emerging crisis” of higher death rates among teenagers and young adults, according to a major study on the causes of death and disability worldwide.The reasons vary from drug and alcohol use, and suicide in North America, to infectious diseases and injuries in sub-Saharan Africa, the researchers said, but warned that their data should serve as “a wake-up call”.In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counsellor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org Continue reading...
items.content: Alcohol, suicide and injuries driving rises among teenagers and young adults despite overall rates falling, authors say The world faces “an emerging crisis” of higher death rates among teenagers and young adults, according to a major study on the causes of death and disability worldwide.The reasons vary from drug and alcohol use, and suicide in North America, to infectious diseases and injuries in sub-Saharan Africa, the researchers said, but warned that their data should serve as “a wake-up call”.In the UK and Ireland, Samaritans can be contacted on freephone 116 123, or email jo@samaritans.org or jo@samaritans.ie. In the US, you can call or text the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 988, chat on 988lifeline.org, or text HOME to 741741 to connect with a crisis counsellor. In Australia, the crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. Other international helplines can be found at befrienders.org Continue reading...

ai_summary: A global health study warns of rising death rates among young people.
Alcohol, suicide, and injuries are driving increases in some areas.
The study highlights an "emerging crisis" in youth mortality.
The reasons vary by region, including drug use and infectious diseases.
The study serves as a "wake-up call" for global health concerns.

clusters.title: My late husband's organs transformed the lives of four people
clusters.neutral_headline: My late husband's organs transformed the lives of four people

items.title: My late husband's organs transformed the lives of four people
items.standfirst: Mark Hutchinson was only 52 when he died unexpectedly last year after suffering two strokes "out of the blue".
items.content: Mark Hutchinson was only 52 when he died unexpectedly last year after suffering two strokes "out of the blue".

ai_summary: Mark Hutchinson died unexpectedly at age 52 from two strokes.
His organs were donated, saving the lives of four people.
The article focuses on the impact of organ donation.
The story highlights the positive outcomes of donation.
The article shares a personal story of loss and giving.

clusters.title: The plastic inside us: how microplastics may be reshaping our bodies and minds
clusters.neutral_headline: Microplastics Found Inside Human Bodies, Potential Health Impacts Explored

items.title: The plastic inside us: how microplastics may be reshaping our bodies and minds
items.standfirst: The particles are in our blood, brains and guts – and scientists are only beginning to learn what they doMicroplastics have been found almost everywhere: in blood, placentas, lungs – even the human brain. One study estimated our cerebral organs alone may contain 5g of the stuff, or roughly a teaspoon. If true, plastic isn’t just wrapped around our food or woven into our clothes: it is lodged deep inside us.Now, researchers suspect these particles may also be meddling with our gut microbes. When Dr Christian Pacher-Deutsch at the University of Graz in Austria exposed gut bacteria from five healthy volunteers to five common microplastics, the bacterial populations shifted – along with the chemicals they produced. Some of these changes mirrored patterns linked to depression and colorectal cancer. Continue reading...
items.content: The particles are in our blood, brains and guts – and scientists are only beginning to learn what they doMicroplastics have been found almost everywhere: in blood, placentas, lungs – even the human brain. One study estimated our cerebral organs alone may contain 5g of the stuff, or roughly a teaspoon. If true, plastic isn’t just wrapped around our food or woven into our clothes: it is lodged deep inside us.Now, researchers suspect these particles may also be meddling with our gut microbes. When Dr Christian Pacher-Deutsch at the University of Graz in Austria exposed gut bacteria from five healthy volunteers to five common microplastics, the bacterial populations shifted – along with the chemicals they produced. Some of these changes mirrored patterns linked to depression and colorectal cancer. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Microplastics have been discovered in blood, brains, and guts, raising concerns about their effects.
Researchers suspect these particles may disrupt gut microbes, altering bacterial populations.
Exposure of gut bacteria to microplastics caused shifts in bacterial populations and chemical production.
Some changes in bacterial production mirrored patterns associated with depression and colorectal cancer.
One study estimated the human brain may contain approximately 5 grams of microplastics.

clusters.title: Diane Keaton, Oscar-winning star of Annie Hall and The Godfather, dies aged 79
clusters.neutral_headline: Diane Keaton, Oscar-Winning Actress, Dies at Age 79

items.title: Diane Keaton, Oscar-winning star of Annie Hall and The Godfather, dies aged 79
items.standfirst: The legendary actor best known for her many collaborations with Woody Allen, as well as films including Reds, The First Wives Club and Book Club, has diedDiane Keaton: a life in picturesPeter Bradshaw on Diane KeatonKeaton interviewed in 2023 and 2014Jess Cartner-Morley on Keaton’s styleDiane Keaton, one of the best-loved film stars of the past 50 years, has died at the age of 79 in California.The news was confirmed by People magazine. Further details are not available at this time and her loved ones have asked for privacy, according to a family spokesperson. Continue reading...
items.content: The legendary actor best known for her many collaborations with Woody Allen, as well as films including Reds, The First Wives Club and Book Club, has diedDiane Keaton: a life in picturesPeter Bradshaw on Diane KeatonKeaton interviewed in 2023 and 2014Jess Cartner-Morley on Keaton’s styleDiane Keaton, one of the best-loved film stars of the past 50 years, has died at the age of 79 in California.The news was confirmed by People magazine. Further details are not available at this time and her loved ones have asked for privacy, according to a family spokesperson. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Diane Keaton, known for films like *Annie Hall* and *The Godfather*, has passed away.
The news of her death was confirmed by People magazine, with no further details released.
Keaton was a beloved film star for over fifty years, leaving a lasting impact.
Her family has requested privacy during this difficult time of mourning.
Keaton collaborated with Woody Allen on numerous films throughout her career.

items.title: Report shows 'stark' gender gap in HIV prevention
items.standfirst: A meeting will discuss how to tackle what organisers say is a growing inequality in HIV prevention.
items.content: A meeting will discuss how to tackle what organisers say is a growing inequality in HIV prevention.

ai_summary: A report reveals a significant gender gap in the area of HIV prevention strategies.
A meeting will address the growing inequality in HIV prevention efforts.
Organizers are working to find solutions to the disparities in HIV prevention.
The meeting aims to discuss ways to tackle the existing inequalities.
The report highlights the need for improved HIV prevention strategies.

clusters.title: TikTok influencers fuelling parallel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug
clusters.neutral_headline: TikTok Influencers Fuel Unlicensed Weight-Loss Drug Market

items.title: TikTok influencers fuelling parallel market for unlicensed weight-loss drug
items.standfirst: Guardian finds a thriving trade on Telegram for retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials and illegal to sellAn online parallel market for an unlicensed weight-loss drug is being fuelled by TikTok fitness influencers and sellers on WhatsApp, a Guardian investigation can reveal.Retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials, is being advertised by social media influencers for its supposed fat-burning effects. Followers are urged to message the accounts privately for supplier links, as well as being provided with discount codes. Continue reading...
items.content: Guardian finds a thriving trade on Telegram for retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials and illegal to sellAn online parallel market for an unlicensed weight-loss drug is being fuelled by TikTok fitness influencers and sellers on WhatsApp, a Guardian investigation can reveal.Retatrutide, which is still in clinical trials, is being advertised by social media influencers for its supposed fat-burning effects. Followers are urged to message the accounts privately for supplier links, as well as being provided with discount codes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A parallel market for the unlicensed weight-loss drug retatrutide is thriving online.
TikTok fitness influencers are advertising retatrutide for its supposed fat-burning effects.
The Guardian investigation revealed a trade on Telegram and WhatsApp for the drug.
Retatrutide is still in clinical trials and illegal to sell at this time.
Influencers provide discount codes and direct followers to private supplier links.

clusters.title: Will UK taxpayers get their £122m back from PPE Medpro?
clusters.neutral_headline: Will UK taxpayers get their £122m back from PPE Medpro?

items.title: Will UK taxpayers get their £122m back from PPE Medpro?
items.standfirst: The high court told the company linked to Michelle Mone to pay up over the supply of defective gowns, but there appears no clear route to reclaim the fundsThe five-year unravelling of Britain’s most high-profile Covid contracts scandal involving a baroness, her husband and multimillion-pound government deals accelerated last week with a high court judgment against the company linked to the former Tory peer Michelle Mone.The judge, Mrs Justice Cockerill, ruled that PPE Medpro, owned by Mone’s husband, the Isle of Man-based businessman Doug Barrowman, supplied defective personal protective equipment (PPE) for use in the NHS during the pandemic. Cockerill ordered that PPE Medpro must return the sum of £122m, which the Department of Health and Social Care paid for the order of 25m sterile surgical gowns, under a contract awarded in June 2020 via the VIP lane. Continue reading...
items.content: The high court told the company linked to Michelle Mone to pay up over the supply of defective gowns, but there appears no clear route to reclaim the fundsThe five-year unravelling of Britain’s most high-profile Covid contracts scandal involving a baroness, her husband and multimillion-pound government deals accelerated last week with a high court judgment against the company linked to the former Tory peer Michelle Mone.The judge, Mrs Justice Cockerill, ruled that PPE Medpro, owned by Mone’s husband, the Isle of Man-based businessman Doug Barrowman, supplied defective personal protective equipment (PPE) for use in the NHS during the pandemic. Cockerill ordered that PPE Medpro must return the sum of £122m, which the Department of Health and Social Care paid for the order of 25m sterile surgical gowns, under a contract awarded in June 2020 via the VIP lane. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The High Court ordered PPE Medpro to repay £122 million over defective PPE gowns.
The company is linked to Michelle Mone, a former Tory peer.
PPE Medpro, owned by Doug Barrowman, supplied defective PPE during the pandemic.
The Department of Health and Social Care paid for 25 million sterile surgical gowns.
The contract was awarded in June 2020 via the VIP lane.
